Gibbs Sampling

Gibbs sampling is a Markov chain Monte Carlo method for sampling from a multivariate probability distribution. It has many applications in inference, Bayesian networks and machine learning. I am a bioinformatician, who needs to sample from joint distributions all the time. What motivated me to write this post is that currently I'm building a Bayesian network for my work, where I need to draw samples from the network. I'll talk about the use of Gibbs sampling in BayesNets in another post.

Let's start with a simple sampling problem. Suppose we have a single variable \( X \) which takes two values:

\( P(X =0)=0.5 \) and \( P(X =1)=0.5 \)

This is an example of binomial distribution. How can get a sample from this distribution? Simply, flip a coin. If it's head, \( X=1 \), else \( X=0 \). The following python code will generate samples from this distribution.

import random

def sampler():
    r = random.random()
    if (r < 0.5):
        X = 0
    else:
        X = 1
    return X


What if you have a multinomial distribution ? Say you want to model the roll of a dice:
$$ P(X = i) = 1/6 , i \in { 1,\ldots ,6 } $$
Divide the interval [0, 1] into 6 equal parts and select the value of \( X \) based on the interval in which a pseudo-random number falls.

def sampler():
    r = random.random()
    if (r < float(1)/6):
        X = 1
    elif (float(1)/6 <= r < float(2)/6):
        X = 2
    elif (float(2)/6 <= r < float(3)/6):
        X = 3
    elif (float(3)/6 <= r < float(4)/6):
        X = 4
    elif (float(5)/6 <= r < float(5)/6):
        X = 5
    else:
        X = 6
    return X


Suppose we have a multivariate distribution -
$$ P(X_1,X_2, \dots,X_n) $$
If the variables are independent of each other (i.e independence assumption, then we have
$$ P(X_1,X_2, \ldots,X_n) = \prod_{i=1}^{n} P(X_i) $$
which will be easy to sample. Draw samples from each of the \( P(X_i) \) individually and then multiply to get a sample of the joint distribution.
People who work with machine learning and data mining would recognize this assumption to be true for Naive Bayes algorithm.

But if the independent assumption doesn't hold, the sampling problem is much harder. Gibbs sampling gives a procedure to sample from a joint probability distribution in terms of conditionals. This efficient method works under one condition:
It is easy to sample from conditional distributions $$ P(X_i | X_1,X_2, \ldots, X_{i-1},X_{i+1}, \ldots X_n) $$ for all \( X_i \)

Algorithm:

￼1. Specify an initial value \( x^{(0)} = (x_1 \ldots ,x_n) \)

  1. Iterate for \( j = 1,2,3,\ldots \)
  • Pick an index \( i \) for \( 1 \leq i \leq n \) uniformly at random.
  • Sample \( x_i \) from \( P(X_{i} | x^{(j-1)}_{(-i)}) \)
  • \( x^{(j)} = (x^{(j-1)}_{(-i)}, x_{i}) \)



The above sampling methodology generates a sequence of samples \( x^{(0)},x^{(1)},\ldots \).

Intuitively, the relation between joint and conditional distributions play an important role in this approximation of joint distribution by conditionals.

$$ P(X_i | X_1,X_2, \ldots, X_{i-1},X_{i+1}, \ldots X_n) = \frac{P(X_1,X_2, \ldots,X_n)}{P(X_1,X_2, \ldots, X_{i-1},X_{i+1}, \ldots X_n)} $$
More theoretically, it can be shown that this sequence forms a Markov Chain over all the possible states. The stationary state of this Markov chain is the sought after joint distribution \( P(X_1,X_2, \ldots,X_n) \). I'll not go into the theory in this post, a curious soul can refer to other resources.

Gibbs sampling is a special case of the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm.

A nice implementation of the basic idea of Gibbs sampling can be found on Darren Wilkinsen's blog.
